abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the National Water Management Project
            (NWMP) in India. The purpose of the project was to increase
            agricultural productivity and farm incomes through a more
            reliable, predictable and equitable irrigation service.
            Bank’s performance was highly satisfactory in identification
            of the project, satisfactory in preparation assistance and
            appraisal and deficient in supervision. Borrower’s
            performance was deficient in preparation and implementation
            and operation. The main lessons learned from this project
            were as follows: a) extensive equitable irrigation and
            self-financing irrigation schemes are two objectives which
            may not be necessarily compatible; b) projects of this type
            which involve not only technical changes to the status quo,
            but also have significant social aspects, require a high
            level of farmer participation in irrigation management (PIM)
            to be successful; c) a baseline survey of the condition of
            the system infrastructure and cropping practices is a
            prerequisite to prepare a detailed scheme report for
            rehabilitation and modernization; d) high quality technical
            assistance and third party supervision should be considered
            in future project; and e) Operation and Maintenance
            (O&M) of the scheme should be jointly carried out by
            department officers and farmer beneficiaries.
